questions.prompt: What standard do Atom and RSS conform with?

Given the following XQuery code:

let $x := doc("courses.xml")/Courses
for $in in $x/Course
where $in/Level > 200
order by $in/Code
return <Course> {$in/Name, $in/Level, $in/Code} </Course>

Which line of the code defines the filter function?

Assume we have five (5) different Web data structures. We choose one structure as the intermediate structure and translate all other structures to and from this structure. How many converters are needed?
The data structure of Google Protocol Buffers is similar to:
Google’s Protocol Buffers are similar in syntax to:

options.label: Class definition of an object-oriented programming language

questions.prompt: What are the key features of a native XML database? Select all that apply.

options.label: No need to load the entire XML into memory
Allow queries for a subset of data in memory
Use the relational database query language

questions.prompt: Using the object-oriented concept of inheritance, what language is the base (parent) language of XQuery?
What are the main problems of using relational databases for XML databases where the XML has an irregular structure? Select all that apply.

options.label: It may create many null columns in a table for representing the data
It may create many tables for representing the data

questions.prompt: Google’s BigTable is used to store:
The idea behind Google’s BigTable is similar to that of:
Which data structures do NOT conform with XML standards? Select all that apply.
Assume we have five (5) different Web data structures, and we want to be able to translate each structure directly to other four (4) structures. How many converters do we need?
A JSON object consists of:
Which of the following are valid JSON values? Select all that apply.
Why do we need JSON instead of using general XML for all applications?

options.label: General XML is too simple to represent fixed data
General XML is a meta-language and can be used to define languages only
General XML represents a collection of data, unlike XML content
JSON is easier and faster for being processed by programming languages

questions.prompt: What web computing models support thin-client architecture? Select all that apply.
AJAX control is implemented in the ASP .Net environment as:
A server control in ASP .Net application (Select all that apply):

options.label: is an object that forms a component in an ASPX page
is executed at the client side
can take input and emit an event upon an input

questions.prompt: A user control:

options.label: is faster in execution than a DLL function
is re-usable in an ASPX page
is a patch on an ASPX page

questions.prompt: Which of the following computing models can be considered to be in thick client architecture? Select all that apply.
What technology best supports the thick client architecture?
What computing model and architecture does Pure HTML Web implement? Select all that apply.
What does the Out-of-browser computing model mean?

options.label: Computing is done on client’s machine
Program is embedded in HTML file

questions.prompt: How are AJAX features implemented in ASP .Net applications?
What are the potential problems of using client-side scripting? Select all that apply.

options.label: Overhead of sending code back and forth
Interpretation is slower than executing compiled code

questions.prompt: AJAX control is implemented in the ASP .Net environment as:
What programming model best supports the thick client in the client-server architecture?
When an ASPX page is accessed from a browser, what is sent to the browser?

options.label: The source code of the ASPX page
An HTML page generated from the ASPX page
The HTML portion of the ASPX page
An XML page generated from the ASPX page

questions.prompt: A user control:

options.label: is always more powerful than a server control
is a component sharable among multiple pages
creates a separate page that can run upon each call

questions.prompt: How do we create an AJAX component in ASP .Net Web applications?

options.label: Create a user control and use parameters to implement the user controls

questions.prompt: The <appSettings> element in Web.config file are typically used for storing:
What are the challenges for defining a global variable in Global.asax file? Select all that apply:

options.label: Create global files that can coordinate with each other
Allow class instances to read the global file
Address the problem of simultaneous write on the variable
Address the performance problem if lock mechanism is used

questions.prompt: When session states are used, a Web server identifies a revisiting browser through an ID:

options.label: associated with the client TCP session

questions.prompt: Where do you store the secure machine key generated for your ASP .Net application?

options.label: In the Web.config file, in the element AppSettings
In the Web.config file, in the element system.web

questions.prompt: How can you prevent Web application deadlock in the case of copying data from one disk file to another disk file?

options.label: Open the two files in two different threads
Close one file before opening the other
Open the two files in random order
Open one for read and the other for write

questions.prompt: Where are the compilation and debugging options of a Web application typically stored in the Web.config file?
Policy-based computing suggests to decouple:
A DLL component that you create:

options.label: must be under the same namespace and you are not required to include it explicitly
forms a namespace and you are required to explicitly include it in the application
forms a service server and you need to use "Add Service Reference" to include it
forms a service server and you need to use "Add Web Reference" to include it

questions.explanation: Session_Start lives in Global.asax so it can track sessions for the whole app.

questions.prompt: Where are the cookies typically stored?

options.label: On the top folder of the application domain on the server
In the ASP.Net folder of your application domain on the server
In the client’s hard drive, in a folder under the browser application
In the client’s hard drive, with the machine config file

questions.prompt: Session state variables can be accessed by:

options.label: the page only in which the session state is defined
the method only in which the session state is initialized

questions.prompt: Why do you need to create your own machine key if your ASP .Net application is hosted in a server farm environment?

options.label: A server farm does not have a machine key
A server farm does not have a unique machine key
A server farm does not need a machine key to generate the hashing ID
ASP .Net applications automatically generate a machine key when hosted in a server farm

questions.prompt: If one selects the cookieless attribute = UseUri to support Session State variables, the restrictions are:

options.label: Browser must remain open to retain session states

questions.prompt: What is the proper order of performing security operations?

options.label: authorization, authentication, and then access of resource
access of resource, authentication, and then authorization
access of resource, authorization, and then authentication
authentication, authorization, and then access of resource

questions.prompt: Availability (A(t)) is probably related to the:

options.label: readiness of service at time point t
the validity and correctness of data and message
continuity of service in time period [0, t]

questions.prompt: In what configuration setting will ASP .Net use the security token passed to it by IIS?

options.label: <identity impersonate = "false" /> (Correct from screenshot — although A & B look identical, B is marked correct)
when impersonation element is not used

questions.prompt: How does the Windows security mechanism work in the Web application security control?

options.label: It blocks IP addresses and domains that are not permitted
It compares the received credential with the credential saved in Windows’s user accounts
It compares the received credential with the credential saved in a user-created XML file
It compares the received credential with the credential saved in the Web.Config file

questions.prompt: The probability that a system has survived in the time interval [0, t] is the system’s:
Reliability R(t) is a probability related to the…

options.label: continuity of service in time period (0, t]
readiness of service at time points
validity and consistency of data and message

questions.explanation: Reliability R(t) models the probability that service continues without failure across (0, t].

questions.prompt: Which dependability attribute ensures the readiness of service at time point t?
questions.explanation: Availability measures readiness for usage at a specific instant.

questions.prompt: In a public key cryptography system aimed at confidentiality, which key should be public?
questions.explanation: Senders encrypt with the recipient's public key; only the private key can decrypt.

questions.prompt: In an open-key cryptography system, which key must be public to preserve confidentiality?
questions.explanation: The sender needs the publicly available encryption key; the private key stays secret.

questions.prompt: Windows security is best suited for which user group when controlling access to a Web site?
questions.explanation: Windows authentication integrates with domain credentials—ideal for intranet scenarios.

questions.prompt: Where can credentials be stored when Forms authentication is used? Select all that apply.

options.label: In the OS access control list

questions.explanation: Credentials may be persisted in system ACLs or in a dedicated user store; Web.config typically references them rather than storing secrets.

questions.prompt: What is the most secure configuration for Forms-based Web security?
questions.explanation: Leaving impersonation disabled (no override) ensures ASP.NET runs under its least-privilege account.

questions.prompt: How should <allow>/<deny> elements be ordered within the authorization section?

options.label: The <deny> elements must be ordered to match authorization requirements

questions.explanation: Authorization rules are evaluated in sequence, so the <deny> entries must be intentionally ordered.

questions.prompt: By default, Forms-auth cookies are protected by… Select all that apply.
questions.explanation: ASP.NET encrypts and signs its auth cookies so they cannot be read or modified by clients.

questions.prompt: Cookies can be used for… Select all that apply.

options.label: Supporting Session State in heavy-traffic clients
Backing up the user data layer independently of the server

questions.explanation: Cookies store lightweight data on clients and can carry session identifiers that back Session State.

questions.prompt: SSL connection between a client and a server is based on a:
How is the WS-ReliableMessaging implemented in WCF?

options.label: A message is resent if no acknowledgment received.
Each message is sent three times.

questions.prompt: In order to detect all two-bit errors, the Hamming distance dₘᵢₙ(C) of code C must be at least:
Wireless communication heavily relies on error control codes. What are the primary error control codes used in 3G cell phone network?
In order to tolerate (or correct) one-bit error, the Hamming distance dₘᵢₙ(C) of code C must be at least:
Data Encryption Standard (DES) is used for low-level security applications, because:

options.label: it has been used for many years.
it is encryption key that is short.
it uses a secretive key system.

questions.prompt: What techniques are used in Data Encryption Standard (DES) to perform encryption and decryption? Select all that apply.

options.label: a simple round of cipher encryption

questions.prompt: Data hashing creates a value from a given data. The hash value:

options.label: can be used for recovering the data using a decryption algorithm.
can uniquely identify a data; cannot recover the data.
creates a digital signature that is mixed with the data.
is generated using the encryption algorithm in the Open Key cryptography system.

questions.prompt: What reliability features does WS-Reliable Messaging specification guarantee? Select all that apply.

options.label: Messages received once and only once

questions.prompt: How is the lost message handled by WS-Reliable Messaging?

options.label: Double redundancy: Each message is sent twice.
Triple redundancy: Each message is sent three times.
A message is resent if no acknowledgment is received within the given amount of time.
The receiver creates the missing message based on the adjacent messages received.

questions.prompt: What are true about the n-out-of-k codes? Select all that apply.

options.label: It may not be able to tolerate all bit single errors.
It has a high level of redundancy, and the cost is high.

questions.prompt: What error control codes are separable codes? Select all that apply.
What error control codes are used in the control channel code standard in 5G wireless network?
Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) defines communication protocols that can provide:
What is the purpose of the fragmentation step in SSL?

options.label: To make the data transmission more efficient
To make the encryption more manageable
To make the transmission more reliable

questions.prompt: What is the advantage of a server-side solution for displaying an XML file in the required format?

options.label: No need to write an XSL style sheet
No special requirement on the web browser

questions.explanation: Rendering on the server frees clients from requiring specific XML/XSL capabilities.

questions.prompt: If an XML file is created in your application, where should it be stored in the ASP.NET application domain?
questions.explanation: App_Data is the designated location for application-generated data files.

questions.prompt: Which of the following terms is NOT defined in the W3C namespace http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema?
questions.explanation: cc:core is not part of the XML Schema namespace.

questions.prompt: A Document Type Definition (DTD) file:

options.label: Defines the syntax/structure of an XML file
Defines the structure of an XML schema file
Extends XML schema with more data types

questions.explanation: DTDs describe which elements/attributes are legal within an XML document.

questions.prompt: What is an empty element in XML? Select all that apply.

options.label: An element without text content between the tags
An element that does not need a separate closing tag (self-closing)

questions.explanation: Empty elements have no textual content or children and can be written using self-closing syntax.

questions.prompt: What XML processing model reads one node into memory at a time?
questions.explanation: SAX streams nodes sequentially rather than loading the whole tree.

questions.prompt: Which representations correctly capture the expression <t> Alan and Mairi. dreamed.? Select all that apply.
questions.explanation: Valid representations wrap the expression in the correct tag and include the verb.

questions.prompt: An XML document has a tree structure. It:

options.label: Can have multiple roots and multiple leaves
Can have multiple roots or records

questions.explanation: Well-formed XML documents always have exactly one root element.

questions.prompt: What are the requirements of a well-formed XML document? Select all that apply.

options.label: There is a single root element
Each element is properly nested between an opening and closing tag
Tags must come from a W3C predefined set
Whitespace is not allowed in text content

questions.explanation: Well-formed XML demands one root and correct nesting.

questions.prompt: Before writing nodes with XmlTextWriter, which operation must be called to properly format the output?
questions.explanation: WriteStartDocument writes the XML declaration and primes the writer.

questions.prompt: Will this piece of code create an in-memory tree to store the entire contents of the XML file “Course.xml”?
questions.explanation: XmlTextReader provides a fast, forward-only, read-only means of accessing data in an XML document. It does not load the entire XML document into memory.

questions.prompt: What line of code (see the numbers right to the code) reads a new node into the memory?
questions.explanation: The `reader.Read()` method on line 3 advances the reader to the next node in the XML document, loading it into memory.

questions.prompt: What does the method “reader.MoveToNextAttribute()” at line 7 return, if the node has no more attribute?
questions.explanation: The `MoveToNextAttribute()` method returns `false` if there are no more attributes to move to.

questions.prompt: An XPath expression allows a function call at the end of the expression.
questions.explanation: XPath functions are invoked within the expression rather than appended after it.

questions.prompt: Which XML processing model reads one node into memory based on a path expression?
questions.explanation: SAX streams nodes one at a time.

questions.prompt: Regarding JAXB processing, which statement is correct?

options.label: Only Marshaller uses an event-driven model
Only DocumentBuilder uses an event-driven model
Both SAXReader and DocumentBuilder use an event-driven model
Neither SAXReader nor DocumentBuilder use an event-driven model

questions.explanation: Both SAXReader and DocumentBuilder rely on event-driven parsing.

questions.prompt: HTML 5.0 is based on:
questions.explanation: Per the lecture notes, HTML5 builds on the CGI-driven model.

questions.prompt: What are the main components of ASPX GUI design? Select all that apply.
questions.explanation: ASPX pages combine HTML controls with server-side controls.

questions.prompt: What are the problems with client-side transformation from XML to HTML? Select all that apply.

options.label: Need to install .NET Framework on the client
Rely on the browser having an XSLT processor
Need to write an XSL style sheet
Need to modify the XML file

questions.explanation: Client transforms require browsers with XSLT support and custom stylesheets.

questions.prompt: What language is used for extending new elements in HTML5?

options.label: Combination of DTD and XML Schema

questions.explanation: Lecture materials specify DTD for extending HTML5 elements.

questions.prompt: XHTML (Extensible HTML) is defined by:
questions.explanation: XHTML is governed by a DTD to enforce XML rules.

questions.prompt: A Document Type Definition (DTD) file:

options.label: Defines the syntax of another DTD file
Is used for defining the structure and syntax of an XML file
Extends the XML syntax model to create more XML schema files

questions.explanation: DTDs constrain the structure of XML documents.

questions.prompt: Given `<!ELEMENT instructor (name, course+, officeHours*, phone | email)>`, which element must appear at least once?
questions.explanation: The + quantifier makes <course> mandatory at least once.

questions.prompt: What does `<!ELEMENT instructor (name+, course?, officeHours*, phone | email)>` imply?
questions.explanation: The ? quantifier marks <course> as optional, whereas name+ requires at least one <name>.

questions.prompt: Why was XML Schema introduced after DTD? Select all that apply.

options.label: DTDs are limited in the amount/type of data they can describe
DTDs are not recommended in new XML scenarios

questions.explanation: XML Schema adds strong typing and uses XML syntax itself, overcoming DTD limits.

questions.prompt: Which language supports an integer data type?
questions.explanation: XSD provides typed elements such as integer; DTD does not.

questions.prompt: Which inputs can you validate with XmlSchemaSet? Select all that apply.
questions.explanation: XmlSchemaSet aggregates schemas and the XML documents to check.

questions.prompt: What is the capacity of XSL as a programming language? Select all that apply.

options.label: It has conditional capabilities comparable to OO languages
It can express conditions using if-then-else
It is Turing complete and supports general computing

questions.explanation: XSLT can branch and iterate, making it computationally complete.

questions.prompt: The Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL) is used for defining transformations of an XML file. Select all that apply.

options.label: It can transform into another XML file with the same or different structure
It is used for massive data storage

questions.explanation: XSL stylesheets are XML documents that describe transformation/styling rules.

questions.prompt: CSS can be applied to define the format of which document types? Select all that apply.
questions.explanation: CSS targets markup languages such as HTML and XML.

questions.prompt: What is XHTML?

options.label: Extensible HTML that uses a DTD to extend HTML
A new version of XML supporting XSL

questions.explanation: XHTML marries HTML semantics with XML constraints via DTDs.
